div1.ab:
Commercial Agency Stanley Falls. Kongo Free State March 17th, 1873
To The Honorable Assistant Secretary of State
Mr. R. Dorsey Mohew
Subject:: Departure from Stanley Pool and arrival at Stanley Falls. Movements of State Troops against rabs
div1.p:
To the Honorable Assistant Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
Sir: I have the honor to inform you of any de- parture from Stanley Pool Febuary 9th and arrival at this place March 9th. The situation there is extremely interesting as the State has began to war against The Arabs who occupy the government ter- ritory to the Eastward of the red line marked on the enclosed charts.

In the South Lieuteniant Dhanis Commisonary of the Kassai District with headquarters at Lousanho Lav with him six thousand men eight hundred State soldiers and five thous- and natives under the command of Kongo Lutete a former slave of Tippo Libs but who declared hundred of free and has thrown his whole force in with the government. This army is marching to Kassongo and Nyangone possibly to Lake Tanhanyka where they would once the hoops of the anti-slave society under command of Captain Jacques. mr. Shanice met the grabs near Nyangons under com- mand of Seffon. (a don of Tippo Tibs) and gained a victory killing one thousand men and capturing twelve hundred garo. The next day the town was captured and the his/ Manci Moharra + his son killed and seffon badly wounded. He is now on his way to Kassongo, after what

his movements are uncertain. This two Arab chiefs killed at Nyangoute were the ones who massacered Mr. Hausters expedition last year between Bena Kamba and Riba Riba. In the month of December. They also killed the two State officers who had been their prisoners for nine months in Kassongo. An expedition consisting of two large river steamers and one thousand one leaves Eavoke this month toco-peperto with Mr. Dhanis using Bepa Kamba as a face of supplies. This force goes down the Lomami River, and to under the command of commandante Charltain. He has been King enough to ask ome to accompany him as his guest and I have accepted the invitation.
This most aggressive action against the Arabs has been taken in accord- ance with chapter I article I para- gratho 2. and 6. of the General Act of Brussels for the oppression of the slave trade.

The Arabs are gradually forcing them- selves to the Westward and are not hunting slaves in the Loptori Tschonapa and Loukenye Rivers. The captured negroes are used as money to purchase ivory and if the ivory is sent to the East Coast they are sold to dealers from the North.

It is impossible for one to write lengthy reports on the subject white I am to constantly on the move, but I have been keeping a journal in which every thing of interest I have so far see is noted and when I finish shall write out a free report and present it to
div1.ab: department in person. I am Sir, Your obident Servant R. Dorsey Mohew Commercial Agent Kongo Free State
One (1) Enclosure Chart Kongo Free State
